raw_text:
Britannia members' £42m windfall
 
 More than 800,000 Britannia Building Society members are to receive a profit share worth on average £52 each.
 
 Members of the UK's second largest building society will share £42m, with 100,000 receiving a windfall of more than £100. Depending on how much they borrow or invest, members earn "reward" points which entitle them to a share of the society's profits. The payouts are bigger than last year, because of stricter eligibility rules. Last year, Britannia members shared £42m, but the average payment was only £38.
 
 To qualify for this year's payment, customers must have been members for at least two years on 31 December 2004. Britannia has also stopped making payments to members if they are worth less than £5.
 
 To qualify for the profit share, members must have either a mortgage, or an investment account other than a deposit account. Customers can also qualify if they have Permanent Interest Bearing Shares (PIBS). The profit share scheme was introduced in 1997 and has paid out more than £370m. Britannia will unveil its results on Wednesday.
llama3.2:1b: Britannia Building Society members are to receive a £42m windfall, with around 800,000 receiving £52 each. To qualify, customers must be at least two years members since December 31, 2004 and have either a mortgage or an investment account. Those who meet the criteria will earn points for their membership that can redeem into profits.

To qualify for the payout, customers must have been members since December 2004 and have either a mortgage or investment account, with certain rules excluding payments worth less than £5.

This is due to stricter eligibility rules that require members to have been members for at least two years and have either a mortgage, an investment account (excluding deposit accounts), or PIBS. The average payment is higher than last year because of more stringent criteria.

qwen2.5:3b: More than 800,000 Britannia Building Society members will receive an average £52 profit share worth up to £100 from a £42m windfall, following stricter eligibility rules compared to last year when the average payment was £38. Members must have been members for at least two years as of 31 December 2004 and qualify with either a mortgage or investment account other than a deposit account. The scheme, introduced in 1997, has paid out more than £370m. Customers who don't meet the minimum value requirement (£5) for profit share payments are excluded. Britannia will reveal its results on Wednesday.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be concise, clear, and free of unnecessary details. Here's how you can achieve this:

1. Identify the main ideas: The text describes the profit share scheme for UK building societies, where members receive a windfall of £42m based on their borrowing or investment amounts.
2. Focus on key concepts: The summary should emphasize the following key concepts:
	* Profit share scheme: A payment made to members based on their income and/or investments.
	* Windfall: A sudden increase in profit, in this case, £42m.
	* Members' average income: £52 per member.
	* Eligibility criteria: Members must have been members for at least two years on 31 December 2004 to qualify for the windfall.
	* Stricter eligibility rules: The payout is bigger than last year, and members must have a mortgage or an investment account other than a deposit account.
3. Avoid unnecessary details: The summary should not include any additional information that is not essential to understanding the main ideas. For example, it does not provide explanations for how the profit share scheme works, nor does it explain the specific eligibility criteria or rules governing the payout.
4. Use clear and concise language: The summary should use simple and straightforward language to convey the main ideas. Avoid using complex sentences or jargon that may confuse readers.

Here's an example of a concise summary in plain text format:

"More than 800,000 Britannia Building Society members are to receive a profit share worth on average £52 each. Members of the UK's second largest building society will earn reward points which entitle them to a share of the society's profits. The payouts are bigger than last year, because of stricter eligibility rules. Last year, Britannia members shared £42m, but the average payment was only £38. To qualify for this year's payment, customers must have been members for at least two years on 31 December 2004. Britannia has also stopped making payments to members if they are worth less than £5."

Next, it states that over 800,000 members will receive average shares worth £52 each, with some getting more than £100 individually. This shows how significant the payout is for individual members, especially those with higher income or investment skills.

The text also explains that members earn "reward" points based on their investments, which are entitled to a share of profits. The payouts being larger this year are partly because these rules have become stricter. It goes back to last year's figure, noting an average payment of £38 instead of the new higher amount.

Furthermore, the summary mentions that members must meet certain criteria: having been a member for at least two years on December 31, 2004; and qualifying through a mortgage or investment account. It also notes that previous members were eligible if they had PIBS shares, and the scheme was introduced in 1997, paying out over £3.7 billion.

Lastly, it'll be revealed who will receive these profits on Wednesday, which adds to the excitement about the announcement.

I need to make sure I include all these key points without adding extra information or explanations. The output should be plain text only.
</think>

The British Building Society members are entitled to a windfall of £42 million, an increase over last year's average payment of £38. Members will receive shares valued on average at £52 each. Some members may receive more than £100 individually due to their investment and borrowing potential. The payouts this year are higher because stricter rules apply. Members must have been a member for at least two years by December 31, 2004, or qualify through a mortgage, investment account, or PIBS shares. The scheme was introduced in 1997 and has paid out more than £3.7 billion. The profits will be revealed on Wednesday.
tinyllama:1.1b: Britannia members' windfall worth an average of £52 each is announced, with over 800,000 getting share payments worth more than £100 and eligibility for payment also stricter. In previous years, a total profit share amounted to just £42m, while the average payout was only £38. To be eligible for payment, customers needed to have been members for at least two years on 31 December 2004 and have either a mortgage or investment account, as well as being under the age of 65. Customers can also meet the criteria if they have PIBS (Permaneint Interest Bearing Shares) or other Investment Accounts. The profit share scheme launched in 1997 and has paid out more than £370m so far. Britannia will announce its results on Wednesday.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
Members of the United Kingdom's second-largest building society, Britannia, are set to receive a windfall worth an average of £52 each as part of their £42 million share in profits. This marks a significant increase from last year, when members shared just £38.

The eligibility criteria for the reward point scheme have been altered this year, with customers being required to have been Britannia members for two years by December 31, 2004. Additionally, to qualify for the payments, members must either be worth less than £5 and hold a Permanent Interest Bearing Shares (PIBS) account or a deposit account. Existing members will receive an email notification on Monday with further details about how to apply for the rewards.

Britannia's profit-sharing scheme has paid out more than £370 million since its introduction in 1997, making it one of the UK's largest pension providers. As a result, the company is set to unveil its financial results on Wednesday.
